thank you so so much for this recipe!﻿

top_comment.author: unknownsilence6

comments.text:
+skatelate2000 I agree, that is why i mentioned that if let to nature every 
(or most) eggs  (just like in humans, not every egg becomes a baby) would 
hatch into its being. Lets no use lauras' recipe for a veg and non veg 
discussion. If you would like to talk more on this topic you can send me a 
private email :)
comments.author: unknownsilence6

comments.text:
+unknownsilence6 Eggs that you buy in the West are unfertilized so no, they 
do not have all the necessary DNA to become a chick. They would need sperm 
from a rooster in order for that to happen.
comments.author: skatelate2000

comments.text:
+skatelate2000 Oh okay. I was under the same misconception since here in 
the west  eggs are considered a dairy product, but from the eastern 
perspective, as I learned, it is considered a meat product since it 
contains all the necessary genetic makeup of a chick since if left to 
nature it would hatch into a living sentient being. To each his own :) I am 
glad to have found one more yummy eggless recipe :)
comments.author: unknownsilence6

comments.text:
+unknownsilence6 oh alright I understand you now. I considered myself 
lacto-ovo when I was a vegetarian as I personally saw no difference between 
eating an egg and drinking milk
comments.author: skatelate2000

comments.text:
+skatelate2000 Lacto-ovo vegetarians consume eggs & milk. Where as I am 
just lacto-vegetarian & consume milk products only as we consider eggs as a 
meat product...i should have specified that in my earlier comment :)
comments.author: unknownsilence6

comments.text: vegetarians can have eggs though...
comments.author: skatelate2000

captions.text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale, and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen, I want to share with

you how to make a no bake peanut butter cheesecake!
It is so easy to do, but it's absolutely divine.

The ingredients you'll need is very few and
simple ones. You'll need some ground graham

crackers, or any kind of like biscuit crackers,
or digestive biscuits. You'll need some peanuts,

a little bit of sugar, some cream cheese that's
been softened at room temperature. You'll

need some smooth peanut butter, confectioner
sugar, vanilla extract, some heavy cream and

some butter. You'll also need some additional
ingredients to make a ganache, but that's

not going to happen until tomorrow - well
tomorrow for me, and like maybe a couple a

minutes for you! Now the first thing you want
to do is get a 9 inch spring form pan, and

spray it with some non-stick spray or just
put a little bit of butter in there, which

is what I've done. And now we're going to
get going on making the crust. We are going

to add - now there's also a pinch of salt
in with the sugar as well for the crust. You

can use salted peanuts and it would be fabulous.
I don't have salted peanuts, I have unsalted

peanuts, which is why I've added a pinch of
salt to my sugar, because the slight saltiness

works really, really well against all the
sweetness of the peanut butter. We are going

to add the butter in, partially - the butter is
just partially melted, not that it really

matters, because it's all going to get whizzed
up anyways. So I'm just going to pulse this

until it gets nice and combined, and the peanuts
have kind of gone into a powder, and it'll

be perfect ! Oh perfect! Looks like wet sand,
and I love that! That's the start of a good

crust. OK. You can smell the peanuts too.
I'm just going to get everything out of here.

Now, if you don't like peanut butter, then
I will direct you to my Nutella - no bake

Nutella cheesecake, which is pretty much kind
of the same thing as this, minus there's no

peanut butter, there is Nutella in there.
So, if you're someone that didn't grow up

eating peanut butter, which I know that all
over the world - when i was a kid in Italy,

I didn't eat peanut butter, didn't even know
such a thing existed. So i grew up eating

Nutella, and it's something that I came to
love and learn when I moved to the States.

So if you're like : "Laura, I don't even know
what peanut butter is, but I can get my hands

on some Nutella or any kind of, sort of chocolate
spread, or maybe a different nut spread",

then you can use this recipe for that! Just
going to press this in really, really well.

And then you can see, I'm just kind of getting
it to come up about half inch the sides of

my baking pan. If you have any pieces that
break like that, just push them right back

together. That looks good enough for me. Now
time to make the filling. I'm going to put

my cream cheese in my standing mixer. You
can do this absolutely in your food processor,

the problem is my food processor's a bit on
the small side, and when I add the cream cheese,

and the peanut butter, and the sugar, and
the cream, it doesn't all get mixed really

well, because it's a smaller one. If it was
a bigger size then it would work perfectly.

So if your food processor is slightly bigger,
you could do it all in the food processor,

and it would save you some washing up. I'm
going to mix the cream cheese by itself for

a couple of minutes to get it really light
and fluffy, and then we'll add in the remaining

ingredients. Bring that down... OK, let's
get all the peanut butter off my spoon, and

all into the cream cheese mixture. Now this
is going to serve a lot of people! So don't

worry, if you're thinking "Whoa, that's a
lot of peanut butter!". It's about a cup and

a half, but again, it's going to serve - let's
see, it's a pretty rich cheesecake, so I'd

say you could get easily between 12 and 16
slices out of this, depending on how thick

you want it. You can get 4 slices out of this,
if you want really big wedges! But, because

something is rich, when something's rich,
especially a dessert, I always do smaller

portions, because you just don't need as much
of it. So keep that in mind. I'm going to

add just a small splash of vanilla, and then
we're going to add in the confectioner sugar,

and - let's get it all out - and then we're
going to add in a little touch of cream. Now

that we have all of our ingredients is there,
lift this up, and mix it all together until

it's combined, and creamy and luscious. Now
this is not a cake batter, this is not cookies,

this is not cupcakes, you cannot, like, overwork
this, and develop gluten or anything. You

just - you want to work this well enough so
that everything is well combined. That is

gorgeous. Looks like peanut butter mousse.
Hey! if all else fails, pass this off as peanut

butter mousse! Oh, I kill myself... I'm so
funny all the time! Anyways, just putting

this into my spring form pan. Try to get it
all out of there, as much of it as you can,

and then just smooth this out. Smells so good!
Something about peanuts, peanut butter - you

just know it's going to be lovely. I do make
a different peanut butter cheesecake which

is baked. It's not no baked like this one,
but the other version that I make is peanut

butter and jelly cheesecake. So if you want
to see that one, then you better comment down

below and let me know. I'm going to cover
this up, I just use a plate, pop it right

on top, and it has to go in to the fridge
overnight. It needs to set, otherwise it's

not going to hold its shape. So I'm just going
to put the plate on top of this, pop it in

the fridge overnight, and then we'll make
a beautiful ganache to go over the top. Now

before we go ahead a unveil the cheesecake
that's been in the fridge overnight, I want

to make a quick little ganache to go over
it. So I've got some semisweet chocolate chips

in here, and this is some hot heavy cream.
I just took some heavy cream, popped it into

this little measuring jug, and I put it in
the microwave for about a minute or until

it got really nice and hot. So I just want
to make sure that the chocolate is submerged

in the hot cream, let it sit there for a second.
Now we've got our cheesecake here, that has

completely set, so if I put my hands on it,
it is perfectly set, and I can smell the peanut

butter immediately! And I think that's like
so inviting, and like, awesome and delicious.

So I'm just going to let the chocolate sit
for about a minute, and then we'll give it

a good whisk, and cover this whole thing with
that deliciously oozy gooey melted chocolate

goodness. I'm going to start giving this a
whisk, and as you whisk it, the chocolate

will melt and melt and melt. And it'll go
from like, this really weird light brown to

a luscious ooey gooey chocolate. Yeah...that
looks awesome! OK, that is good. Now what

we need to do is cover the top of our cheesecake
with that lovely chocolate. Let it ooze out,

let it kind of run all over the top, because
we need to put this back into the fridge to

set. It'll take maybe an hour or so. You want
that chocolate to set completely. That's good

enough. Let's get it covered all over, beautiful!
In the fridge until the chocolate is fully

set. Yup, here we go! Now, truth be told,
you really do need to have this sit in the

fridge until the chocolate's completely set,
I've only kept it in there for 10 minutes.

My greed is getting the best of me! But it
smells amazing, it's holding up just fine,

so I don't have to worry about it. What I
do have here is a wet kitchen towel or - you

need something wet - because it makes getting
clean slices much better, if you have something

that you can wipe your knife on. You get really
nice neat slices like that. I'm just going

to cut myself a slice. Look at that...Look
at the chocolate, the smooth peanut butter,

and that graham cracker peanut crumb mixture...
I can't. If you like Reese's Peanut butter

cups, I will put my last earned dollar, put
my name on the fact that this tastes exactly

like it, but 10 times better. It just does
- it's, I, it's - This, you can call it Reese's

Peanut butter cheesecake, if you wanted to,
but it is my peanut butter cheesecake, so

that's how we're going to call it. It is just
phenomenal. It's incredibly rich, yet not

overpowering at all. It's smooth, it hold
such beautiful texture. The combination of,

like, the crumble, the peanut butter layer,
and the chocolate is just dynamite! I just

couldn't - I can't picture anybody not falling
in love with this, because it is just absolutely

divine. And a small piece goes a long way.
This slice, believe it or not, hold yourself

down, is even too big for me, because it is
such a rich cheesecake that you really don't

need a whole lot to appreciate the flavor
and enjoy it. laurainthekitchen.com has the

recipe for you. Let me know if you do make
it, and please tag me all over whether it's

Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, because I would
love to see your recreations. I hope you've

enjoyed spending time with me guys, and I'll
see you next time. Bye bye!

title: No Bake Peanut Butter Cheesecake Recipe - Laura Vitale - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 763
